meaningMnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tranquilize</kanji>, so the verb version is what happens when you've already been able to tranquilize someone. It's <vocabulary>to appease</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to suppress</vocabulary>.
readingMnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You want <vocabulary>to appease</vocabulary> her because <reading>she's</reading> (しず) SUPER mad. She's pissed and she's angry and she's going to beat you up if you don't find out how <vocabulary>to calm</vocabulary> her down!
